channel.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
channel.description:
I've searched for things like this on Google, but I haven't found an useful information about what I'm looking for.
How would I make a button go below another button in a Java GUI. I'd like two buttons, then below them, another one.

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Somewhere around here.

Read full topic
item.source: Simple Question about a Java GUI

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

I have a good one:

FlowLayout, its default.

          JPanel panel1 = new JPanel();
                    panel1.add(button1);
          this.add(panel1); //or JFrame.add(panel1);
          JPanel panel2 = new JPanel();
                    panel2.add(button2);
          this.add(panel2); //or JFrame.add(panel2);
          JPanel panel3 = new JPanel();
                    panel3.add(button3);
          this.add(panel3); //or JFrame.add(panel3);

          this.setVisible(true);

This would be somewhere close on how to use…

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Nashi:

That looks really really hard White D:

All it is, is this: your layout manager now manages components based on coordinates within the pane, with each set (0, 0; 0, 1) representing where a component is going to be drawn. To add all of the buttons below the last one, use the following piece of code:

setLayout(new GridBagLayout()); GridBagConstraints constraints = new GridBagConstraints(); for(JButton button : new JButton[] {new JButton("Top"), new JButton("Middle"), new JButton("Bottom")}) { //add button listeners (i.e. button.addActionListener(actionListener)), etc. add(button, constraints); constraints.gridy++; }

Read full topic
item.source: Simple Question about a Java GUI

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“remove_later, post:3, topic:142476”][quote author=1337h4x link=topic=194920.msg1750867#msg1750867 date=1189581427]
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/
[/quote]
Eww.
Give this kid atleast the Abstract Window Toolkit API or, a much better thing in my humble opinion, teach him to make his own GUI API.[/quote]
He’s using swing, and most java developers are quite happy to use the given API rather than create their own. If he’s asking a question this simple, do you really think he wants to create an entire UI library?

Read full topic
item.source: Simple Question about a Java GUI

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

do what howlinghawk, except you have to specify a LayoutManger so it goes right, differant managers do differant things when you add components.

i think grid layout is good for you, try this

frame.setLayout(new GridLayout(NUMBER_OF_BUTTONS_HERE, 1));
frame.add(button that you want to appear here first);
frame.add(button that you want to appear here second);

pwnd, I feel i should tell you that null layout is baaad :), since when you resize a window, everything stays in the same place and makes no sence, so you have to make your JFrame non-resizable
But with layout managers, it takes care of everything for you, and you only have to learn them a little

Read full topic
item.source: Simple Question about a Java GUI

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

i think you’re trying to get the buttons to overlap, so like the top half of one button is covered by another button

i think you can do this with JLayeredPane, iv never really used those before, but the screenshots on sun’s site look like its what you need
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/components/layeredpane.html

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Question about a Java GUI
item.dc:creator: @Nashi Nashi
item.description:
@Nashi wrote:

That looks really really hard White D:

try:
import java.awt.FlowLayout

setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.CENTER)); //Or some other stuffs

Has always worked for me
